oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: John Ross
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: A half-length portrait of John Ross wearing a suit. He is shown seated at a desk with letters on the desktop, to indicate the literacy of the Cherokee.

John Ross was born in Turkeytown, Alabama, October 3, 1790, and died in Washington, D.C., on August 1, 1866. He was the Principal Chief of the Cherokee from 1828 until his death. He was the first and only elected Chief of the Cherokee Nation from the time it was formed until his death. He was highly regarded for his role in leading the fight against removal and leading the Cherokees to their exile in Oklahoma. The town John Ross founded as Ross's Landing was renamed Chattanooga, Tennessee.
